I will never stop fighting for the rights of workers everywhere - from demanding NLRB accountability to passing major labor law reform like the #PROAct to fighting to improve the standard of living for every American. 11//
Workers‚Äô ability to come together in solidarity to win higher wages, better benefits, & safer workplaces is always crucial, but especially during a pandemic. 10/

The bill undoes the harmful prohibition of electronic voting in union elections and requires the NLRB to conduct elections remotely due to the public health risks of in-person voting during the coronavirus pandemic. 9/
In response to this egregious attack on both our right to organize and our democracy I introduced the SAFE Workers Act, which protects workers‚Äô safety while preserving organizing efforts. 8/

Worse, NLRB leaders have taken advantage of the pandemic to forward their anti-worker agenda.
 
They‚Äôve blunted organizing by temporarily suspending all union elections. Recently, they halted scheduled elections that were set to use the safer mail-ballot process. 7/

This includes barriers for the NLRB‚Äôs own employees. Dedicated career staff are saddled with a politically appointed leadership team that is seemingly hellbent on making staffers‚Äô jobs more difficult and weakening the agency from the inside.  6/
Instead of fulfilling this duty, the Trump NLRB has turned its back on workers by stripping them of their rights, allowing employers to evade the law, and throwing up barriers wherever possible. 5/

The NLRB is disregarding its legal mandate. The National Labor Relations Act, which created the NLRB, outlines that it was made for ‚Äúprotecting the exercise by workers of full freedom of association, self-organization, and designation of representatives of their own choosing.‚Äù 4/
Filling an agency meant to protect workers with the very corporate bosses who are taking advantage of those workers is unacceptable. 3/
Trump has stocked NLRB leadership with union busters and corporate lawyers. Unsurprisingly, the board has sided with corporate interests over workers at every turn. 2/

I know this is a complicated and sometimes confusing issue (especially as President Trump demands repealing Sec. 230 for very different reasons). If you have questions, please post them, and I'll try to reply later tonight.

The government shouldn't dictate what speech private companies allow on their sites. But if they amplify certain speech in ways that harm people, they should not be immune from normal liability. I hope that legal risk will encourage them to design their networks differently.

Our bill says that if social media companies use algorithms to amplify or recommend content that leads to serious offline harm, like acts of terrorism, they can be held liable (thus narrowly waiving the immunity Sec. 230 of the Telecommunications & Decency Act gives them now).

The companies have figured out that negative emotions keep us glued to our screens longest. So they feed us increasingly hateful versions of what we hate and fearful versions of what we fear. This is one reason our country has become so divided, and why extremism has grown.

If you click on cute animal videos and shoe ads, you'll see more of them. Likewise, if you click on a white supremacist or QAnon-style video, Facebook & Google will recommend more, until that dangerous content crowds out all else and becomes your individually tailored reality.

Here's the problem: We once got our information from journalists who tried to make responsible decisions about what was important and true. Today, social media algorithms decide what news and information we see, based on what they think we want to see.

The big social media companies have been playing whack-a-mole taking down extremist content one post and group at a time. But they resist changing the design of a social network that's built to amplify extremism.

Today, @RepAnnaEshoo & I are introducing a bill to change that.
